i don't know....every article i've found that addresses the decreased fatality rate is listing 'severity' of the illness as a possible factor which i'm translating as 'viral load'. it could be 'severity' is distinct from load? i don't think so though.

no matter what way you cut it....starting with 100 units will cause a greater growth rate than starting with 100,000 units. the idea is....when you start with a low load your immune system has a chance to fight it. a high load your immune system is overwhelmed from the get-go.
one of the articles stated that doctors think 100 units are necessary for infection (i thought it would be wayyy more than that). so let's go with 100.
this helps in that regard:
the more i google this...the stronger the consensus seems to be. viral load directly impacts the severity of the infection:
to be clear....i'm saying that viral load might explain why the fatality rate is dropping significantly....not that it's making covid more or less contagious.
potential high dose exposure of clinical staff conducting procedures on patients who are not known to be infected.""

“for most of us, it’s hard to see how we could receive such a high dose; it’s going to be a rare event. in the covid-19 clinic, the purpose of ppe is to prevent such large exposures leading to high dose infection. situations we should be concerned about are....

"under such circumstances the virus receives a massive jump start, leading to a massive innate immune response, which will struggle to control the virus to allow time for acquired immunity to kick-in while at the same time leading to considerable inflammation and a cytokine storm

it's true that we have no confirmation....but there is general consensus that viral load might be (or is) a factor: https://www.sciencemediacentre.org/expert-reaction-to-questions-about-covid-19-and-viral-load/
a higher viral load would mean you're starting on say, day 15 of the month. which the curve is already straight up. exponential growth curves start slow and become drastic.

this isn't true. think of the 'one grain of rice' fable. the whole point of that fable is to show that the exponential outcome is not evident during the first week (or during the beginning of an exponential growth curve) in context of the fable...

the circumstantial evidence that points to viral load relevance is that we've measured a much higher fatality rate for ppl under 40 who were infected in hospitals and or senior homes (including soldiers, nurses, doctors, etc) than those infected in other public places.

contrary to popular perception....modern music (ie the past 30 years) have really emphasized arrangement over songwriting. and often, in the linear notes, those credited with 'songwriting' are in fact, arrangers more than songwriters.
/3 producer: like a film director, oversees each and every other role. fini

/2 engineer: how each instrument sounds? how each instrument is recorded? mixer: how all instruments of the song are blended together to make a whole. mastering: similar to mixer but rather than blending elements of a song...they blend songs of a record together for cohesion.

/1 lil' thread defining roles in music production. not exact science and there's overlap but a rough guide: songwriting: lyrics, chords, chord changes, melodies, key changes arrangement: what instruments are used? what each individual instrument plays? time signature, groove

to clarify...it's not exactly true that the r0 'does not change'. r0 changes as the virus changes. we can never know the 'true' r0 just like we can never know the true length of the coast of an island. the r0 is fixed with the evolution of the germ. the r changes as we act.

to my understanding...the r0 is static to the same extent as the virus is static. any social factor, including immunity, is the r. not the r0. (ie the r changes even if the virus doesnt, the r0 does not)

the r0 assumes no mitigation and no human knowledge of germs. but even so...given the covid1 factors in respect to post recovery...under deed immunity policy tge average person would contract it multiple times. we don't know what the outcomes are for multiple infections.
is that good enough to validate a policy of herd immunity? at an r0 between 5 and 6 i can't see how we'd avoid a scenario where we would all experience multiple infections.

a scenario of herd immunity given these conditions would be an endless cycle of contraction. we'd get it as soon as our antibodies wore off. and we have no idea what happens with compounding infections.
if post-recovery immunity lasts between 6 months to 2 years....i can't see how herd immunity is a viable strategy. covid19 is estimated to be 5 to 6 times more contagious than the flu.

any person who becomes a representative of a governing party can be fairly asked about past assertions. if they resort to "well let's talk about what someone else said"...they are not fit to represent governance. it's a postmodernist technique of whataboutism.

'the media' (a boogeyman term if one ever existed) or 'media'? because we have the most diverse media in the history of human civilization.
this a false dichotomy. a representative of a governing body cannot, legitimately, point the finger back at an imaginary "monolith media consensus" (that never existed) in response to media critique.

in a healthy democracy the media represents the diversity of public opinion. a governing party represents a consensus of the majority. treating the public discourse as a battle between the 'fed govt vs the media' is an inherently anti-democratic lens.
this is the most basic point that dismantles this false equivalence between critique of trump and critique of 'the media'.
no they do not. diversity of viewpoint on an editorial board of a newspaper is a virtue. diversity of viewpoint in a governing party is failed leadership.

absolutely incorrect. contradicting editorial pieces from a media company are indicative of a healthy org fulfilling their societal role. contradicting statements from a federal govt institution are indicative of failed leadership.
you don't get to say 'wapo says so and so' because they printed an article that said so and so. that's not how it works. that is...however....how a federal govt administration works.

any critique of the media that implies they are a monolith or that published articles represent a consensus among various editorial boards represent an inherently flawed view of the role of a free press in a democracy.
the statement made in the video suggests that an article published by wapo or nyt is supposed to represent the same type of consensus that exists in statements from the white house. which is insane.

hip hop is a postmodern artform too (by virtue of creating new music out of pre-existing recordings ie sampling). the idea of turning a record player into an instrument is a postmodern approach.

the term 'classical' is widely misused technically speaking. mozart is 'classical music'. early beethoven is sometimes called 'classical' but his later music is 'romantic'. ex of a modernist composer is stravinsky. ex of a postmodern composer is phillip glass.

if it appears as though i'm going off on a tangent....my assertion is that the two addictions are like apples and oranges. completely different from each other. and this distinction is reflected in distinct recividism rates. opiate withdrawal is it's own beast. it's a marathon.

a common cliche among addicts: heroin is like water/food. crack is like cake. you need the heroin. the crack is a luxury. and opiates can be used to sail through crack withdrawals without any discomforth. you can't use crack to sail through opiate withdrawals.

3 to 4 days into opiate withdrawal....you haven't even necessarily peaked in discomfort depending on the time release mechanism of what you were using. whereas with crack-cocaine....you're basically outta the woods (physically speaking)

i think of crack withdrawal as an extended hangover essentially. we're usually talking 3 to 4 days. a couple sleeping pills. a healthy meal. and this seems true even for habitual users. opiate withdrawal is weeks.

ok but paws is not what i think of as day 21 of an oxycodone withdrawal. paws is day 90 of sobriety. during day 21 you are still in the acute phase of oxycodone withdrawal (albeit less acute than day 5). this is distinct from meth/coke/crack/dexedrine, any stimulant.

differentiating packing snow from powder snow from slushy snow etc. a society that never sees snow has no use for these categories. the categories themselves are not in nature. we identify and establish categories when it becomes beneficial to do so.

most of us heard the cliche 'the inuit have 100 different words for snow'. apparently it's not true....but that's the point i'm making here. our systems of classification are determined by function/usefulness. that's what is meant by social construct. the inuit have a use in....
from any set of data....the number of ways in which to classify or categorize it is a variable.

we still needed to decide where to plant flags and how many flags to plant in establishing our race categories. the level of abstraction we choose to use is a variable. we could have made 1000s of categories. we could have made 3.

the argument here does not deny that group based differences can be identified in humans. but the categories we divide ourselves up into are not cleanly determined by these differences...as often assumed. nor are they universal....they vary cross-culturally.

this is a super complicated issue but one note here: it's only descendants of west african societies that are at risk of sickle cell (which is why it's common in us) yet the term 'black' is also used in the us for ppl descendant from east african societies (who arent at risk).

i'm not a trained fighter so it was really just luck. what surprised me most is how vulnerable someone is when you're holding their foot at head level. i could have gently nudged him wherever i wanted and he would've went flying.
